item.title: Pain Science in Practice (Part 8): Nociceptive, Neuropathic and Nociplastic Pain
item.description: Feld: Clinical Medicine Kategorie: Rehabilitation Score: 24 Autoren: Morten Hoegh, Paul Hodges Journal: Journal of Orthopaedic & Sports Physical Therapy Veröffentlicht: 2025-07-29 Abstract: Identification of pain descriptors provide a plausible method to consider personalisation of management of pain based on presumed underlying mechanisms. The aim is to use mechanistic pain descriptors (nociceptive, neuropathic and nociplastic pain) to guide clinical practice into an era of personalised medicine for people with pain. Clinicians should understand the concept of descriptors to improve their understanding of a mechanism-based management of chronic pain. Nonetheless, all treatment of individuals suffering from chronic pain should be holistic (i.e., person-centred). Nociplastic pain already serves as an evidence-based explanation that can help make sense of pain without any known pathology, but is not ready to be considered as a target for treatment in itself, based on the current level of evidence. To summarise, treatment outcomes may benefit when treatments are matched to patients according to mechanistic descriptors, and current research initiatives are working on bring this closer to the clinic. DOI: 10.2519/jospt.2025.13335 ISSN: 0190-6011 Tag der Erhebung (OOIR): 2025-08-09

item.title: Training on Childhood Apraxia of Speech: Experiences of Speech-Language Pathologists
item.description:
Feld: Clinical Medicine Kategorie: Rehabilitation Score: 17 Autoren: Sydney Keller, Hannah Valentine, Daphna Harel, Maria I. Grigos Journal: American Journal of Speech-Language Pathology Veröffentlicht: 2025-07-29 Abstract: Purpose: The diagnosis and treatment of childhood apraxia of speech (CAS) remains a clinical challenge for many speech-language pathologists (SLPs). Given this, it is imperative to understand how SLPs learn about CAS during graduate school and throughout their careers.
Method: In the current study, American Speech-Language-Hearing Association–certified SLPs who practice in the United States and work with young children completed a 32-item online survey. Survey items aimed to understand SLPs' experiences learning about CAS during graduate school and through continuing education (CE). Respondents were evaluated on their knowledge of diagnosing and treating CAS (against an expert consensus). Finally, the survey sought to investigate how respondents' learning experiences related to their knowledge of diagnosing and treating CAS.
Results:
In total, 346 clinicians completed the survey. Reliance on CE ( p < .001) and scientific literature in SLP ( p < .01) were found to be the only positive significant predictors of CAS knowledge. No graduate school experiences positively predicted CAS knowledge. The majority of clinicians indicated being unprepared to diagnose and treat CAS based on their graduate-level education but reported high levels of satisfaction for CE resources for CAS.
Conclusions: Results of this study highlight challenges in graduate program models for training on CAS. Implications for graduate program models are discussed.
DOI: 10.1044/2025_ajslp-24-00224 ISSN: 1058-0360 Tag der Erhebung (OOIR): 2025-08-09
